js
Class JSTable

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  js.JSTable
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class JSTable
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.awt.event.MouseListener

JSTable is a solution for creating a simple JTable. The table is placed into a panel along with a title label.

Changing the class for columns:


Each column of a JSTable must be told what data type is to be displayed in it. To do this, special characters are used at the end of heading names, like so:

String headings[] = {"Code#", "Name", "Price$", "In Stock~"};

This code would create a four-column table, the first being an Integer column, the second containing Strings, the third containing Doubles and a Boolean checkbox in the fourth.

To recap, the symbols to use are:
  • # (hash) for an Integer
  • $ (dollar sign) for a Double
  • ~ (tilde) for a Boolean checkbox
  • No symbol for a String
It's also fine to use these symbols in the heading names themselves, such as "Product ##", which will produce an Integer column named "Product #".

Usage

 String[] headings = {"Code#", "Name", "Price$", "In Stock~"}; // set up an array containing the table's headings
 
 JSTable table = new JSTable("Product List", headings, 0);     // initialise the table with a title of Product List,
                                                               // the previously specified headings and no initial rows
                                                                                                                   
 table.centerAllColumns(); // convenience method instead of calling centerColumn() for every column
 
 table.setBounds(20, 20, 400, 300);
 aFrame.add(table);

Version:
1.2.2
Author:
Josh Sunshine
See Also:
Serialized Form

sortByColumn

public void sortByColumn(int column)
Sorts the table into ascending order by the values in the specified column. If this method is called on the same column twice consecutively, the sort order is changed to descending.

Parameters:
column - the column to sort the table by

centerAllColumns

public void centerAllColumns()
Deprecated. - This method has been replaced with a more powerful method, setColumnAlignment, which allows not only center alignment but also right alignment as well. This method will be removed completely in version 1.2.3 (or the third new version of JSTable).

Centers the text in every column of the table.

centerColumn

public void centerColumn(int column)
Deprecated. - This method has been replaced with a more powerful method, setColumnAlignment, which allows not only center alignment but also right alignment as well. This method will be removed completely in version 1.2.3 (or the third new version of JSTable).

Sets the horizontal alignment of the text in the specified column to centered.

Parameters:
column - the column to center the text of.

centerHeaders

public void centerHeaders()
Deprecated. - This method has been replaced with a more powerful method, setHeaderAlignment, which allows not only center alignment but also right alignment as well. This method will be removed completely in version 1.2.3 (or the third new version of JSTable).

Sets the horizontal alignment of the table header text to centered.

makeDialog

public javax.swing.JDialog makeDialog()
Deprecated. This method does not provide adequate support for using a modal dialog and waiting for user input after being displayed. It is recommended that you use a JSTableDialog instead of a regular JSTable.

Create a new JDialog containing the table, title and buttons. Do not call this method if you plan on using the table as a panel.

makeDialog

public javax.swing.JDialog makeDialog(javax.swing.JPanel northPanel,
                                      javax.swing.JPanel southPanel)
Deprecated. This method does not provide adequate support for using a modal dialog and waiting for user input after being displayed. It is recommended that you use a JSTableDialog instead of a regular JSTable.

Create a new JDialog containing the table, title and buttons. Up to two other panels can also be added, one above and one below the table. Do not call this method if you plan on using the table as a panel.

Parameters:
northPanel - the panel to be added above the table.
southPanel - the panel to be added below the table.
Returns:
a centered JDialog containing the table and any extra panels.
